general: This law makes sure that the UK leaves the European Union (EU). It sets out the rules for how this will happen and what will happen after the UK leaves. The law also makes some other changes related to the UK's departure from the EU.

series.short: "UK Government's Regulatory Power During Implementation Period"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has the power to make regulations related to the implementation period of the withdrawal agreement, which includes provisions for modifying existing laws and making new provisions as needed.
* Simplified point 2: The power to make regulations is exercisable by the UK government, either alone or jointly with devolved authorities (such as the Scottish and Welsh governments), and can be used to modify or make new provisions in relation to Part 4 of the withdrawal agreement.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations made under this power can include provisions for other modifications, exceptions, and exemptions related to the implementation period, and can be made up to two years after the IP completion day.
* Simplified point 4: The power to make regulations is subject to certain requirements, such as the need for consent, joint exercise, or consultation, and the provision must be within the devolved competence of the devolved authority.
* Simplified point 5: The meaning of devolved competence is defined in the legislation and includes provisions that would be within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament, the National Assembly for Wales, or the Northern Ireland Assembly if they were contained in an Act of that Parliament.

series.short: "Withdrawal Agreement Legal Framework Established"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation ensures that the rights, powers, liabilities, obligations, restrictions, remedies, and procedures established by the withdrawal agreement are given legal effect and enforced in domestic law.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation applies to all aspects of the withdrawal agreement, including the EEA EFTA separation agreement and the Swiss citizens’ rights agreement, and ensures that these agreements are recognized and available in domestic law.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation provides for the implementation of the withdrawal agreement without further enactment, and ensures that all enactments (including those contained in the Act) are read and have effect subject to the provisions of the withdrawal agreement.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation includes provisions for the recognition and enforcement of rights, powers, liabilities, obligations, restrictions, remedies, and procedures established by the withdrawal agreement, and provides for the interpretation of law relating to the withdrawal agreement and related agreements.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation includes provisions for the use of powers involving devolved authorities in connection with certain other separation issues and the Ireland/Northern Ireland Protocol.

series.short: "UK Government Regulation on Residence Rights for EU Citizens After Brexit"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government can make regulations to specify deadlines for EU citizens to apply for residence in the UK after Brexit.
* Simplified point 2: The regulations can also provide temporary protection for EU citizens who have not yet applied for residence but are living in the UK before the deadline.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can modify existing laws and immigration rules to implement these provisions.
* Simplified point 4: The regulations can apply to both EU citizens who are eligible for residence and those who are not eligible but have been granted leave to enter or remain in the UK.
* Simplified point 5: The regulations can also provide for the protection of Swiss nationals in the UK.

series.short: "UK Frontier Worker Rights Regulations: Ensuring Seamless Transition Post-Brexit"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government can make regulations to implement the rights of frontier workers (those who work in one country but live in another) under the Withdrawal Agreement, the EEA EFTA separation agreement, and the Swiss citizens' rights agreement.
* Simplified point 2: These regulations can modify existing provisions made by or under the Immigration Acts.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can provide for the issue of documents to frontier workers, such as proof of their right to work or reside in a particular country.
* Simplified point 4: The regulations can also provide for the implementation of Articles 23-26 of the withdrawal agreement, the EEA EFTA separation agreement, and the Swiss citizens' rights agreement, which relate to the rights of frontier workers.

series.short: "UK Border Control Regulations: Restricting Rights of Entry & Residence After Brexit"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government can make regulations to restrict the rights of entry and residence for certain individuals, as outlined in the withdrawal agreement, EEA EFTA separation agreement, and Swiss citizens' rights agreement.
* Simplified point 2: These regulations can apply to both individuals who are covered by the agreements and those who are not, and can modify existing provisions made by or under the Immigration Acts or other primary legislation.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can also be made to apply to individuals who have been denied entry clearance or leave to enter or remain in the UK, including those who have been subject to deportation orders or other decisions restricting their right to enter the country.
* Simplified point 4: The purpose of these regulations is to implement the restrictions of rights of entry and residence outlined in the withdrawal agreement, EEA EFTA separation agreement, and Swiss citizens' rights agreement, in order to ensure that the UK can control its borders and manage immigration after leaving the EU.

series.short: "UK Deports Foreign Criminals Post-Brexit: Complex Rules Apply"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is allowed to deport foreign criminals who have committed crimes before the UK's withdrawal from the EU, but only if their deportation does not breach the UK's obligations under the EU withdrawal agreement, EEA EFTA separation agreement, or Swiss citizens' rights agreement.
* Simplified point 2: The UK government is not allowed to deport foreign criminals who have committed crimes before the UK's withdrawal from the EU if their deportation would breach the UK's obligations under the EU withdrawal agreement, EEA EFTA separation agreement, or Swiss citizens' rights agreement.
* Simplified point 3: The UK government is not allowed to recommend that a foreign criminal be deported if the offence for which they were convicted consisted of or included conduct that took place before the UK's withdrawal from the EU.
* Simplified point 4: The UK government is not allowed to deport a foreign criminal if they have a right to enter the UK by virtue of the EU withdrawal agreement, EEA EFTA separation agreement, or Swiss citizens' rights agreement, whether or not they have been granted such leave.
* Simplified point 5: The UK government is not allowed to deport a foreign criminal if they may enter the UK by virtue of regulations made under section 8 of the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Act 2020 (frontier workers), whether or not they have entered by virtue of those regulations.

The extract also provides that the Authority will be referred to as "the IMA" in this Part of the Act, and that Schedule 2 contains provisions related to its constitution and functions. summary: The European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Act 2020 is a law passed by the UK parliament to ensure that the rights, powers, liabilities, obligations, restrictions, remedies, and procedures established by the withdrawal agreement are given legal effect and enforced in domestic law. The act applies to all aspects of the withdrawal agreement, including the EEA EFTA separation agreement and the Swiss citizens’ rights agreement, and ensures that these agreements are recognized and available in domestic law. The UK government has the power to make regulations related to the implementation period of the withdrawal agreement, which includes provisions for modifying existing laws and making new provisions as needed. The regulations can include provisions for other modifications, exceptions, and exemptions related to the implementation period, and can be made up to two years after the IP completion day. Additionally, the UK government can make regulations to specify deadlines for EU citizens to apply for residence in the UK after Brexit, provide temporary protection for EU citizens who have not yet applied for residence, and implement the rights of frontier workers under the Withdrawal Agreement, the EEA EFTA separation agreement, and the Swiss citizens' rights agreement. Finally, the UK government can pay money to the EU or EU entities to meet any obligations it has under the withdrawal agreement, and must review EU legislation during the implementation period and report back to Parliament on any matters of vital national interest.
